title: The Gift of Wisdom
devotional:
Old Man Tiberius, the village woodcarver, wasn't known for his speed. In fact, some whispered he was slower than a snail in winter. But what he lacked in haste, he more than made up for in artistry and wisdom. He crafted each piece with meticulous care, imbuing it with stories and insights gleaned from a lifetime of observing the world. People came from miles around not just for his carvings, but for his counsel.

One blustery winter evening, a young man named Ethan, eager to make his mark on the world, sought out Tiberius. Ethan was brimming with ambition but felt lost, unsure of which path to take. He confessed his anxieties to the old carver, lamenting the lack of clarity in his life.

Tiberius listened patiently, his eyes twinkling like embers in the hearth. When Ethan finished, the old man didn't offer a grand pronouncement or a detailed plan. Instead, he simply picked up a gnarled piece of wood and began to carve. He worked in silence for what seemed like an eternity, his weathered hands moving with practiced grace. Finally, he held up the finished piece – a small, unassuming owl.

"The owl," Tiberius said softly, "is a symbol of wisdom. But its wisdom doesn't come from knowing all the answers, but from keen observation, patient listening, and the ability to see clearly even in the dark. You seek a grand plan, Ethan, but wisdom often lies in taking small, deliberate steps, paying attention to the signs along the way. Don't rush. Observe. Listen. And trust that the path will reveal itself as you walk it."

Ethan, initially expecting a more definitive answer, felt a sense of calm wash over him. He realized that wisdom wasn't about having all the answers beforehand, but about cultivating the ability to discern the right course, step by step, guided by observation and intuition. He left Tiberius's workshop that evening not with a clear roadmap, but with a compass – the wisdom to navigate the uncertainties of life.
image_description: A close-up of an intricately carved wooden owl, resting on a workbench with wood shavings scattered around it.
insights: The story of Tiberius and Ethan illustrates that wisdom is not merely intellectual knowledge, but a practical understanding of how to live well in the world. Proverbs 4:7 states, 'Wisdom is the principal thing; therefore get wisdom: and with all thy getting get understanding.' This verse highlights that wisdom is paramount, requiring active pursuit and diligent application. James 1:5 adds, 'If any of you lacks wisdom, you should ask God, who gives generously to all without finding fault, and it will be given to you,' reminding us that wisdom is a gift from God, available to those who seek it in humility and faith.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you seeking wisdom. Grant me the ability to observe the world around me with discernment, to listen attentively to your guidance, and to trust that you will lead me on the right path. Help me to cultivate patience and understanding, knowing that wisdom is a journey, not a destination. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may make wise choices and live a life that honors you. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what area of your life are you currently seeking wisdom? What steps can you take to cultivate greater discernment and understanding? How can you practice the art of observation and listening, allowing God to guide you on your journey?
